   left
   temporal lobe compared to MR one month ago. DDx includes neoplasm
   such as lymphoma (apparent mild enhancement of right temporal focus
   relative
   to background brain parenchyma; though the short-interval change argues

   though
   CT density of only ~ 44, and no corresponding abnormality on GRE argue
   against). Pituitary mass again seen. MRA/MRV: No vascular occlusion or

   thrombosis. [**Doctor Last Name 5284**] D/W Dr. [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 3127**] (medicine resident) 11:45 p
   [**2144-12-24**].
   CT head:
   Study limited by motion (though 5 attempts made). However, impression
   of
   mildly increased density diffusely, interdigitating with sulci,
   especially
   near skull base. Given the concern for hemorrhage, and lack of IV
   contrast
   administration, this may represent subarachnoid hemorrhage. MRI had
   already
   been ordered, but discussed with Dr. [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 3127**] 9p [**2144-12-24**].
   Assessment and Plan
 DECUBITUS ULCER (PRESENT AT ADMISSION)
 RESPIRATORY FAILURE, ACUTE (NOT ARDS/[**Doctor Last Name 2**])
 [**Last Name **] PROBLEM - ENTER DESCRIPTION IN COMMENTS
   Acute Mental Status Change, Pituitary Macroadenoma, Acromegaly
 LYMPHOMA (CANCER, MALIGNANT NEOPLASM, LYMPHOID)
   41 yo gentleman with h/o acromegaly and high grade B-cell lymphoma (s/p
   admission at [**Hospital1 1**] from [**2144-7-11**] to [**2144-11-12**]) who was transferred
   from [**Hospital6 797**] following episode of altered mental status
   early today that led to intubation for airway protection.
   #. Altered mental status:  Patient
s mental status changes severe
   enough to warrant intubation for airway protection. Initial concern for
   intracerebral hemorrhage given Head CT report from [**Hospital3 1573**], aniscoria, systemic anticoagulation with enoxaparin, and
   report of acute mental status changes. Possible etiologies of ICH would
   be an ischemic stroke with hemorrhagic conversion, spontaneous bleed in
   setting of systemic anticoagulation, or unrealized trauma.   STAT head
   CT here (limited by motion) was able to rule out massive hemorrhage
   causing herniation, though still possibility of small hermorrhage.
   Additionally, this presentation could represent a recurrence of his
   lymphoma, which was formerly thought to be in remission. Must consider
   that observed behavior and resulting mental status changes at [**Hospital 9798**] were consistent with a seizure. Is possible that
   patient's serotonergic medications of citalopram, nortriptyline, and
   dilaudid acted to create a serotonin syndrome that presented with
   patient turning head to right due to increased tone. On physical exam
   at this time, muscle tone is essentially normal and patient has no
   history of fevers or clonus at OSH. Must also consider that his
   presentation is related to meningitis or encephalitis, though no
   prodrome of illness aside from nausea and vomiting and no reported
   fevers. As for other infections, should screen with blood culture, UA
   (was seen to have [**6-24**] RBCs and WBCs at OSH), and CXR. No elevation in
   livier enzymes and ammonia of 27 at [**Hospital3 **], both of which are
   inconsistent with a hepatic encephalopathy.
   MRI here with ?hemorrhage versus malignancy.  In the settind of
   elevated LDH, this could be an indication of recurrent disease. Phos
   decreased dramatically which could have caused a metabolic
   encephaolpathy or precipitated a seizure.
   - Will keep patient intubated for now pending LP.
   - Appreciate neurology consult input
   - Appreciate neurosurgery consult input
   - am labs after phos repletion
   - Hold on further dilaudid or nortriptyline at this time, though may
   continue to give citalopram to aboid withdrawal from SSRI
   - hodl LP for now
   - blood cultures Uctx to screen for additional sources of infection
   that can cause acute mental status changes
   # Respiratory failure: sputum and consolidation on CXR suggest possible
   healthcare associated pneumonia
   - sent sputum ctx
   - plan for 10 day course with Vancomycin/Cefepime pending ctx data
   #  hypophosphatemia: unclear etiology.  Unknown why it would be due to
   decreased absorption.  Also could be from increased losses.  Unlikely
hungry bone
 given normal calcium.   Could contribute to MS changes at
   this low of a level.
   -check PTH
   -urine lyes
   -repeat levels later this am
   #. Nausea and vomiting:
   Patient's original presenting complaint to [**Hospital6 797**] was
   nausea and vomiting. Abdominal films and upper GI series have yet been
   unrevealing. Some concern that this may be attributed to increased ICH
   in setting of known pituitary macroadenoma or new recurrence of NCS
   lymphoma.
   - Treat supportively with ondansetron
   #. Report of abnormal EKG:
   Copy of EKG was not sent with patient; however, reportedly had diffuse
   ST and T changes that were attributed to nausea and vomiting and
   resulting electrolyte abnormalities. Two sets of cardiac enzymes were
   reportedly negative at [**Hospital6 797**]. ECHO was performed and
   showed anteroseptal akinesis of left ventricle, which is new
   -EKG here unchanged from 2 prior with exception of ?U waves
   - TEE to fully assess
   # Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma:
   Patient is reportedly in remission after hyper-CVAD, R-[**Hospital1 **], HD
   methotrexate, and intrathecal methotrexate. Possible his AMS is related
   to recurrence of his lymphoma.
   - Appreciate consultation from BMT service- consult heme/onc this am
   - Consider LP to rule out recurrent CNS lymphoma however unclear if can
   do this in the setting of MRI changes
   # Acromegaly and Pituitary Macroadenoma:
   Recent labs to check HPA showed normal TSH, LH, testosterone, and
   cortisol with slightly high FSH (14, ULN: 12) and high prolactin at 26
   (ULN: 15).
   - Will eventually need surgical resection that was to be set up on
   outpatient basis; though, appointment with neurosurgery was [**2144-12-24**]
   and will need to be rescheduled
   # Sacral decubitus ulcer:
   Reportedly a stage IV ulcer with recent pseudomonal infection. Appears
   to be without obvious infection at this time as drainage is
   serosanguinous.
   - Wound care consult
   - Potential surgery consult for further debridement pending full
   evaluation from wound care team
   # Constipation:
   - Standing polyethylene glycol and senna
   - PRN bisacodyl and lactulose
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: NPO for now
   Glycemic Control: None indicated at this time, will initiate QID
   fingersticks if serum glucose elevated
   Lines:  18 Gauge - [**2144-12-24**] 04:36 PM, Indwelling Port (PortaCath) -
   [**2144-12-24**] 04:37 PM, 20 Gauge - [**2144-12-24**] 06:33 PM
   Prophylaxis:
   - DVT ppx with pneumoboots while patient has contraindication to
   anticoagulation
   - Lansoprazole for stress ulcer prophylaxis
   - Bowel regimen with senna, polyethylene glycol, bisacodyl, lactulose
   - Pain management with acetaminophen

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 41-year-old male with a history of acromegaly and high-grade B-cell lymphoma who was transferred from another hospital due to an episode of altered mental status that led to intubation for airway protection.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory failure: The patient is intubated and on ventilator support due to respiratory failure.
* Altered mental status: The patient's mental status is severely altered, and the patient is unable to follow commands or open his eyes.
* Hypophosphatemia: The patient has low phosphate levels, which may be contributing to his altered mental status.
* Nausea and vomiting: The patient has been experiencing nausea and vomiting, which may be related to his altered mental status or other underlying conditions.
* Abnormal EKG: The patient's EKG shows diffuse ST and T changes that may be related to electrolyte abnormalities.
* Lymphoma: The patient has a history of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, which may be recurrent.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen if not adequately managed.
* Altered mental status: The patient's altered mental status may persist or worsen if not addressed.
* Hypophosphatemia: The patient's hypophosphatemia may worsen if not treated, which may lead to further complications.
* Nausea and vomiting: The patient's nausea and vomiting may lead to dehydration and electrolyte imbalances if not managed.
* Abnormal EKG: The patient's abnormal EKG may indicate underlying cardiac conditions that need to be addressed.
* Lymphoma: The patient's lymphoma may recur or progress if not adequately managed.

The patient's current treatment plan includes:

* Intubation and ventilator support for respiratory failure
* Supportive care for altered mental status, including management of hypophosphatemia and electrolyte imbalances
* Treatment of nausea and vomiting with ondansetron and other medications
* Management of abnormal EKG with further evaluation and treatment as necessary
* Follow-up with hematology and oncology services to address the patient's lymphoma

The patient's code status is full code, and his disposition is ICU care for now.

   #. Altered mental status:  Patient
s mental status changes severe
   enough to warrant intubation for airway protection. Initial concern for
   intracerebral hemorrhage given Head CT report from [**Hospital3 1573**], aniscoria, systemic anticoagulation with enoxaparin, and
   report of acute mental status changes. Possible etiologies of ICH would
   be an ischemic stroke with hemorrhagic conversion, spontaneous bleed in
   setting of systemic anticoagulation, or unrealized trauma.   STAT head
   CT here (limited by motion) was able to rule out massive hemorrhage
   causing herniation, though still possibility of small hermorrhage.
   Additionally, this presentation could represent a recurrence of his
   lymphoma, which was formerly thought to be in remission. Must consider
   that observed behavior and resulting mental status changes at [**Hospital 9798**] were consistent with a seizure. Is possible that
   patient's serotonergic medications of citalopram, nortriptyline, and
   dilaudid acted to create a serotonin syndrome that presented with
   patient turning head to right due to increased tone. On physical exam
   at this time, muscle tone is essentially normal and patient has no
   history of fevers or clonus at OSH. Must also consider that his
   presentation is related to meningitis or encephalitis, though no
   prodrome of illness aside from nausea and vomiting and no reported
   fevers. As for other infections, should screen with blood culture, UA
   (was seen to have [**6-24**] RBCs and WBCs at OSH), and CXR. No elevation in
   livier enzymes and ammonia of 27 at [**Hospital3 **], both of which are
   inconsistent with a hepatic encephalopathy.
   MRI here with ?hemorrhage versus malignancy.  In the settind of

 given normal calcium.   Could contribute to MS changes at

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 41-year-old male with a history of acromegaly and high-grade B-cell lymphoma, who was transferred from another hospital after an episode of altered mental status and intubation for airway protection. The patient's current condition is:

* Respiratory failure, acute (not ARDS)
* Decubitus ulcer (present at admission)
* Altered mental status
* Hypophosphatemia
* Nausea and vomiting
* Abnormal EKG
* Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (reportedly in remission)
* Acromegaly and pituitary macroadenoma
* Sacral decubitus ulcer (stage IV)
* Constipation

The patient is currently receiving various medications, including:

* Midazolam (Versed) for sedation
* Ondansetron for nausea
* Citalopram for anxiety
* Fentanyl for pain management
* Acetaminophen for pain management
* Lansoprazole for stress ulcer prophylaxis
* Polyethylene glycol and senna for bowel regimen

* TCO2: 23
* Glucose: 90
* Other labs: PT/PTT/INR: 15.9/31.5/1.4, ALT/AST: 9-29, Alk Phos/T Bili: 72/0.3, Differential-Neuts: 85.0%, Lymph: 9.2%, Mono: 4.2%, Eos: 1.4%, Albumin: 3.6 g/dL, LDH: 489 IU/L, Ca++: 8.0 mg/dL, Mg++: 1.9 mg/dL, PO4: 0.8 mg/dL

The patient's MRI shows:

* Abnormal hyperintensity on T2/FLAIR in the right temporal lobe and anterior left temporal lobe compared to the previous MRI, which may be indicative of neoplasm, such as lymphoma, or acute hemorrhage.

The patient's CT head shows:

* Mildly increased density diffusely, interdigitating with sulci, especially near the skull base, which may represent subarachnoid hemorrhage.

The patient's physical examination shows:

* NAD, withdraws arms to pain, follows commands by squeezing hands but not opening eyes, pectus excavatum, large jaw, and hands
* CV: RRR nl s1/s2 no m
* Pulm: CTA b/l
* Abd: +BS, soft NTND
* Neuro: PERRL but sluggish

The patient's assessment and plan include:

* Attempt to liberate from sedation overnight to assess the patient's underlying mental status, then consider extubation if no neurosurgical involvement
* Appreciate neurology consult input
* Appreciate neurosurgery consult input
* Am labs after phosphorus repletion
* Hold on further dilaudid or nortriptyline at this time, though may continue to give citalopram to avoid withdrawal from SSRI
* Hold LP for now
* CXR, blood cultures, and UA to screen for additional sources of infection that can cause acute mental status changes
* Check PTH
* Urine lytes
* Repeat levels later this am

Potential medical complications that can arise from this patient's condition include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure can worsen if not managed properly, leading to further complications such as pneumonia or respiratory arrest.
* Decubitus ulcer: The patient's decubitus ulcer can become infected, leading to sepsis and other complications.
* Altered mental status: The patient's altered mental status can worsen if not managed properly, leading to further complications such as seizures or status epilepticus.
* Hypophosphatemia: The patient's hypophosphatemia can worsen if not managed properly, leading to further complications such as muscle weakness or respiratory failure.
* Nausea and vomiting: The patient's nausea and vomiting can worsen if not managed properly, leading to dehydration and electrolyte imbalances.
* Abnormal EKG: The patient's abnormal EKG can worsen if not managed properly, leading to further complications such as cardiac arrhythmias or cardiac arrest.
* Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma: The patient's diffuse large B-cell lymphoma can relapse or progress, leading to further complications such as central nervous system involvement or multi-organ failure.
* Acromegaly and pituitary macroadenoma: The patient's acromegaly and pituitary macroadenoma can worsen if not managed properly, leading to further complications such as hypopituitarism or hyperthyroidism.
* Sacral decubitus ulcer: The patient's sacral decubitus ulcer can become infected, leading to sepsis and other complications.

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and manage any potential complications promptly and effectively to prevent further deterioration and improve the patient's outcomes.

   41 yo gentleman with h/o acromegaly and high grade B-cell lymphoma (s/p
   admission at [**Hospital1 1**] from [**2144-7-11**] to [**2144-11-12**]) who was transferred
   from [**Hospital6 797**] following episode of altered mental status
   early today that led to intubation for airway protection.
   #. Altered mental status:  Patient
s mental status changes severe
   enough to warrant intubation for airway protection. Initial concern for
   intracerebral hemorrhage given Head CT report from [**Hospital3 1573**], aniscoria, systemic anticoagulation with enoxaparin, and
   report of acute mental status changes. Possible etiologies of ICH would
   be an ischemic stroke with hemorrhagic conversion, spontaneous bleed in
   setting of systemic anticoagulation, or unrealized trauma.   STAT head
   CT here (limited by motion) was able to rule out massive hemorrhage
   causing herniation, though still possibility of small hermorrhage.
   Additionally, this presentation could represent a recurrence of his
   lymphoma, which was formerly thought to be in remission. Must consider
   that observed behavior and resulting mental status changes at [**Hospital 9798**] were consistent with a seizure. Is possible that
   patient's serotonergic medications of citalopram, nortriptyline, and
   dilaudid acted to create a serotonin syndrome that presented with
   patient turning head to right due to increased tone. On physical exam
   at this time, muscle tone is essentially normal and patient has no
   history of fevers or clonus at OSH. Must also consider that his
   presentation is related to meningitis or encephalitis, though no
   prodrome of illness aside from nausea and vomiting and no reported
   fevers. As for other infections, should screen with blood culture, UA
   (was seen to have [**6-24**] RBCs and WBCs at OSH), and CXR. No elevation in
   livier enzymes and ammonia of 27 at [**Hospital3 **], both of which are
   inconsistent with a hepatic encephalopathy.
   MRI here with ?hemorrhage versus malignancy.  In the settind of
   elevated LDH, this could be an indication of recurrent disease. Phos
   decreased dramatically which could have caused a metabolic
   encephaolpathy or precipitated a seizure.
   - Attempt to liberate from sedation overnight to assess patient's
   underlying mental status, then consider extubation if no neurosurg
   involvement
   - Appreciate neurology consult input
   - Appreciate neurosurgery consult input
   - am labs after phos repletion
   - Hold on further dilaudid or nortriptyline at this time, though may
   continue to give citalopram to aboid withdrawal from SSRI
   - hodl LP for now
   - CXR, blood cultures, and UA to screen for additional sources of
   infection that can cause acute mental status changes
   #. Nausea and vomiting:
   Patient's original presenting complaint to [**Hospital6 797**] was
   nausea and vomiting. Abdominal films and upper GI series have yet been
   unrevealing. Some concern that this may be attributed to increased ICH
   in setting of known pituitary macroadenoma or new recurrence of NCS
   lymphoma.
   - Treat supportively with ondansetron
   #. Report of abnormal EKG:
   Copy of EKG was not sent with patient; however, reportedly had diffuse
   ST and T changes that were attributed to nausea and vomiting and
   resulting electrolyte abnormalities. Two sets of cardiac enzymes were
   reportedly negative at [**Hospital6 797**]. ECHO was performed and
   showed anteroseptal akinesis of left ventricle, which is new
   -EKG here unchanged from 2 prior with exception of ?U waves
   - Consider TEE to fully assess
   # Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma:
   Patient is reportedly in remission after hyper-CVAD, R-[**Hospital1 **], HD
   methotrexate, and intrathecal methotrexate. Possible his AMS is related
   to recurrence of his lymphoma.
   - Appreciate consultation from BMT service- consult heme/onc this am
   - Consider LP to rule out recurrent CNS lymphoma however unclear if can
   do this in the setting of MRI changes
   # Acromegaly and Pituitary Macroadenoma:
   Recent labs to check HPA showed normal TSH, LH, testosterone, and
   cortisol with slightly high FSH (14, ULN: 12) and high prolactin at 26
   (ULN: 15).
   - Will eventually need surgical resection that was to be set up on
   outpatient basis; though, appointment with neurosurgery was [**2144-12-24**]
   and will need to be rescheduled
   # Sacral decubitus ulcer:
   Reportedly a stage IV ulcer with recent pseudomonal infection. Appears
   to be without obvious infection at this time as drainage is

   - Wound care consult
   - Potential surgery consult for further debridement pending full

Based on the patient's progress note, the following potential medical complications can arise:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient is on invasive ventilation, which increases the risk of respiratory failure, ventilator-associated pneumonia, and tracheal injury.
2. Decubitus ulcer: The patient has a sacral decubitus ulcer, which can worsen with prolonged immobility and increase the risk of infection.
3. Constipation: The patient is at risk of developing constipation due to the use of anticholinergics, opioids, and other medications.
4. Nausea and vomiting: The patient's nausea and vomiting can lead to dehydration, electrolyte imbalances, and aspiration pneumonia.
5. Seizures: The patient's altered mental status and MRI findings suggest a risk of seizures, which can be life-threatening.
6. Infection: The patient is at risk of developing infections, including pneumonia, urinary tract infections, and bloodstream infections, due to his immunocompromised state and invasive devices.
7. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's anticoagulation therapy and underlying bleeding disorder increase the risk of gastrointestinal bleeding.
8. Hyperglycemia: The patient's recent glucose levels are high, which can lead to hyperglycemic crises, ketoacidosis, and other complications.
9. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension can lead to organ dysfunction, including cardiac, renal, and hepatic failure.
10. Cardiovascular complications: The patient's anticoagulation therapy and underlying cardiovascular disease increase the risk of cardiovascular complications, including cardiac arrhythmias, myocardial infarction, and stroke.

To mitigate these risks, the patient requires close monitoring and management by a multidisciplinary team, including intensivists, pulmonologists, neurologists, and other specialists.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 41-year-old male with a history of acromegaly and high-grade B-cell lymphoma who was transferred from another hospital after an episode of altered mental status. He is currently intubated for airway protection and is being treated for suspected healthcare-associated pneumonia.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated LDH and preliminary LP results suggesting recurrent lymphoma. The MRI scan revealed diffuse leptomeningeal enhancement and FLAIR hyperintensity involving the right greater than left temporal and parietal lobes, with more focal areas of parenchymal abnormality in the temporal lobe.

The patient's medical conditions include:

1. Recurrent diffuse large B-cell lymphoma: The patient is reportedly in remission after hyper-CVAD, R-Hyper-CVAD, HD methotrexate, and intrathecal methotrexate, but the LP suggests that he is having a recurrence.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient has been intubated for airway protection and is being treated for suspected healthcare-associated pneumonia.
3. Nausea and vomiting: The patient's original presenting complaint was nausea and vomiting, which is likely related to increased intracranial pressure given the high opening LP pressure.
4. History of DVT: The patient had a DVT in the past and is currently being treated with heparin gtt for anticoagulation.
5. Abnormal EKG: The patient's EKG showed diffuse ST and T changes, which were attributed to nausea and vomiting and resulting electrolyte abnormalities.
6. Acromegaly and Pituitary Macroadenoma: The patient has a history of acromegaly and a pituitary macroadenoma, which will require surgical resection at a later time.
7. Sacral decubitus ulcer: The patient has a stage IV sacral decubitus ulcer with a recent pseudomonal infection.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Meningitis: Given the patient's history of lymphoma and the presence of leptomeningeal enhancement on MRI, there is a risk of meningitis.
2. Seizures: The patient's altered mental status and the presence of abnormal EEG findings suggest a risk of seizures.
3. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure may worsen if not treated promptly and effectively.
4. Sepsis: The patient's fever and leukocytosis suggest a risk of sepsis.
5. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's nausea and vomiting may lead to gastrointestinal bleeding.
6. DVT: The patient's history of DVT and the presence of a central line increase the risk of DVT.
7. Infection: The patient's compromised immune system and the presence of a central line increase the risk of infection.

The patient's treatment plan includes:

1. Antibiotics for suspected healthcare-associated pneumonia.
2. Dexamethasone for possible meningitis.
3. Heparin gtt for anticoagulation.
4. Pain management with acetaminophen.
5. Wound care for the sacral decubitus ulcer.
6. Follow-up LP results and heme/path.
7. Further evaluation and treatment for the patient's recurrent lymphoma.

The patient's code status is full code, and his disposition is ICU care for now.

Summary:

The patient is a 41-year-old man with a history of acromegaly, high-grade B-cell lymphoma, and pituitary macroadenoma. He was admitted to the ICU with altered mental status, respiratory failure, and hypophosphatemia. His condition is complicated by the possibility of recurrent lymphoma in the CNS, infection, or hemorrhage. The patient has undergone various tests, including a lumbar puncture, transesophageal echocardiogram, and MRI, which have revealed leptomeningeal enhancement and parenchymal abnormality in the temporal and parietal lobes.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Recurrent lymphoma: The patient's altered mental status and respiratory failure may be due to recurrence of lymphoma in the CNS.
2. Infection: The patient's sputum culture and CSF analysis have revealed Gram-positive cocci, which may indicate a bacterial infection.
3. Hemorrhage: The patient's MRI has revealed areas of decreased diffusion, which may indicate acute infarcts or hemorrhage.
4. Hypophosphatemia: The patient's hypophosphatemia may be due to decreased absorption, increased losses, or an underlying metabolic disorder.
5. Nausea and vomiting: The patient's nausea and vomiting may be due to increased ICH in the setting of a known pituitary macroadenoma or new recurrence of NCS lymphoma.
6. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure may be due to healthcare-associated pneumonia or other underlying respiratory conditions.
7. Sacral decubitus ulcer: The patient's sacral decubitus ulcer may be prone to infection and requires wound care and potential surgery.

Assessment and Plan:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's mental status and respiratory function.
2. Perform further tests to rule out recurrent lymphoma, including a repeat lumbar puncture and CSF analysis.
3. Administer antibiotics for suspected bacterial infection.
4. Manage hypophosphatemia with phosphate supplements and monitor for signs of hypocalcemia.
5. Continue to treat nausea and vomiting supportively with ondansetron.
6. Monitor the patient's respiratory function and consider extubation if possible.
7. Provide wound care for the sacral decubitus ulcer and consider surgery if necessary.
8. Consult with neurology, neurosurgery, and hematology/oncology services to further evaluate and manage the patient's condition.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 41-year-old male with a history of acromegaly and high-grade B-cell lymphoma, who was admitted to the ICU after experiencing altered mental status and was intubated for airway protection. The patient self-extubated and is now experiencing respiratory failure.

The patient's current medical conditions include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient is experiencing respiratory failure, which is likely due to a combination of factors, including pneumonia, respiratory muscle weakness, and increased intracranial pressure.
2. Decubitus ulcer: The patient has a stage IV sacral decubitus ulcer that is currently without obvious infection.
3. Lymphoma: The patient has a history of high-grade B-cell lymphoma and is currently experiencing a recurrence, which is likely affecting his mental status and respiratory function.
4. Acromegaly: The patient has a history of acromegaly and pituitary macroadenoma, which is affecting his hormone levels and causing symptoms such as fatigue, weakness, and joint pain.
5. Pituitary macroadenoma: The patient has a pituitary macroadenoma that is affecting his hormone levels and causing symptoms such as fatigue, weakness, and joint pain.
6. Nausea and vomiting: The patient is experiencing nausea and vomiting, which is likely related to increased intracranial pressure and/or chemotherapy.
7. Rash: The patient has a rash that is likely drug-related, possibly due to vancomycin.

The patient's laboratory results show:

1. Elevated LDH: The patient's LDH levels are elevated, which is consistent with lymphoma recurrence.
2. Elevated WBC count: The patient's WBC count is elevated, which is consistent with infection or inflammation.
3. Low platelet count: The patient's platelet count is low, which is consistent with lymphoma recurrence or chemotherapy.
4. Elevated CRP: The patient's CRP levels are elevated, which is consistent with infection or inflammation.

The patient's imaging studies show:

1. CXR: The patient's CXR shows consolidation and sputum, which is consistent with pneumonia.
2. Head CT: The patient's head CT shows no signs of massive hemorrhage or herniation, but may show small hemorrhage or malignancy.
3. MRI: The patient's MRI shows no signs of hemorrhage or malignancy.

The patient's medications include:

1. Dexamethasone: The patient is receiving dexamethasone for respiratory failure and nausea and vomiting.
2. Vancomycin: The patient is receiving vancomycin for respiratory failure and possible pneumonia.
3. Cefepime: The patient is receiving cefepime for respiratory failure and possible pneumonia.
4. Lovenox: The patient is receiving Lovenox for anticoagulation.
5. Metoprolol: The patient is receiving metoprolol for hypertension.
6. Ondansetron: The patient is receiving ondansetron for nausea and vomiting.
7. Citalopram: The patient is receiving citalopram for depression.

The patient's plan of care includes:

1. Continue dexamethasone for respiratory failure and nausea and vomiting.
2. Continue vancomycin and cefepime for respiratory failure and possible pneumonia.
3. Restart Lovenox for anticoagulation.
4. Monitor the patient's mental status and respiratory function closely.
5. Perform a head CT and MRI to rule out small hemorrhage or malignancy.
6. Consider surgical resection of the pituitary macroadenoma once the patient's malignancy workup and treatment are complete.
7. Continue wound care for the sacral decubitus ulcer.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 41-year-old male with a history of acromegaly and high-grade B-cell lymphoma who was admitted to the ICU after a self-extubation. The patient has a complex medical condition with multiple comorbidities, including respiratory failure, lymphoma, and decubitus ulcer.

The patient's current vital signs are:

* Temperature: 37°C (98.6°F)
* Heart rate: 108 beats per minute
* Blood pressure: 144/96 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 28 breaths per minute
* SpO2: 100%

The patient's laboratory results show:

* WBC: 6.7 x 10^9/L
* Hct: 37.6%
* Plt: 60 x 10^9/L
* Cr: 0.5 mg/dL
* TCO2: 23 mmHg
* Glucose: 95 mg/dL
* LDH: 681 IU/L
* Ca++: 8.4 mg/dL
* Mg++: 1.8 mg/dL
* PO4: 1.4 mg/dL

The patient has a decubitus ulcer on his sacrum, which is reportedly a stage IV ulcer with recent pseudomonal infection. The patient also has a respiratory failure, which is likely related to his lymphoma and possible healthcare-associated pneumonia.

The patient's medications include:

* Dexamethasone 4 mg IV q6h
* Vancomycin 1 g IV q12h
* Cefepime 2 g IV q8h
* Lovenox 70 mg SQ q12h
* Metoprolol 12.5 mg IV q6h
* Ondansetron 8 mg IV q8h
* Citalopram 20 mg PO qd
* Bisacodyl 5 mg PO qhs
* Magnesium sulfate 20% IV

The patient's plan includes:

* Continue dexamethasone 4 mg IV q6h
* F/u sputum ctx
* Plan for 10-day course of vancomycin and cefepime
* Restart lovenox for anticoagulation
* Treat supportively with ondansetron and dexamethasone for nausea and vomiting
* Monitor for signs of infection and sepsis
* Continue to monitor for respiratory failure and adjust therapy as necessary

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

* Respiratory failure and pneumonia
* Decubitus ulcer infection
* Lymphoma recurrence and progression
* Seizures and altered mental status
* Nausea and vomiting
* DVT and PE
* Cardiovascular complications, including arrhythmias and heart failure
* Infection and sepsis

It is essential to continue to monitor the patient's condition closely and adjust therapy as necessary to prevent these complications and improve the patient's outcome.

Summary:

The patient is a 41-year-old male with a history of acromegaly, high-grade B-cell lymphoma, and a recent episode of altered mental status leading to intubation for airway protection. He was transferred to the ICU from another hospital and was found to have a decubitus ulcer, respiratory failure, and a rash. The patient self-extubated and is now on invasive ventilation. He has a history of DVT and is on anticoagulation therapy with Lovenox. The patient's condition is complex, with multiple medical issues, including lymphoma, respiratory failure, and altered mental status.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely due to pneumonia, which is confirmed by the presence of consolidation on CXR. The patient is at risk of developing respiratory failure due to the underlying disease and the need for invasive ventilation.
2. Decubitus Ulcer: The patient has a stage IV decubitus ulcer, which is at risk of progressing to deeper tissue damage and potentially life-threatening complications.
3. Lymphoma Recurrence: The patient's recent LP results suggest recurrent lymphoma, which is a life-threatening condition that requires immediate attention and treatment.
4. Infection: The patient's elevated LDH and preliminary LP results suggest the possibility of infection, which could be related to the lymphoma or other underlying conditions.
5. Hemorrhage: The patient's altered mental status and elevated opening LP pressure suggest the possibility of hemorrhage, which could be related to the lymphoma or other underlying conditions.
6. Seizure: The patient's altered mental status and elevated LDH suggest the possibility of seizure, which could be related to the lymphoma or other underlying conditions.
7. Nausea and Vomiting: The patient's nausea and vomiting are likely related to increased ICP and may require supportive treatment.
8. DVT: The patient has a history of DVT and is at risk of developing DVT again, which could lead to life-threatening complications.
9. Acromegaly and Pituitary Macroadenoma: The patient's acromegaly and pituitary macroadenoma may require surgical resection, which could be complicated by the patient's underlying medical conditions.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and provide supportive care as needed.
2. Consult with neurology and neurosurgery to determine the best course of treatment for the patient's altered mental status and potential seizures.
3. Consult with oncology to determine the best course of treatment for the patient's lymphoma recurrence.
4. Continue to monitor the patient's decubitus ulcer and provide wound care as needed.
5. Consult with infectious disease to determine the best course of treatment for the patient's potential infection.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's DVT and provide anticoagulation therapy as needed.
7. Consult with endocrinology to determine the best course of treatment for the patient's acromegaly and pituitary macroadenoma.
8. Consider imaging studies, such as MRI or CT scans, to determine the extent of the patient's lymphoma and potential complications.

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 41-year-old gentleman with a history of acromegaly and high-grade B-cell lymphoma who was admitted to the ICU due to altered mental status and respiratory failure. The patient has been experiencing worsening altered mental status despite less sedation, which is likely due to the recurrence of lymphoma in the CNS.

The patient has several potential medical complications:

1. Increased intracranial pressure (ICP): The patient's worsening altered mental status and increasing LDH levels suggest a possible increase in ICP. A stat CT head is recommended to assess for herniation or increased ICP.
2. Central diabetes insipidus: The patient's increased urine output and known increased ICP may indicate central diabetes insipidus. The patient's D51/2NS should be stopped to minimize worsening cerebral edema, and urine lytes and serum lytes should be checked.
3. Healthcare-associated pneumonia: The patient's sputum and consolidation on CXR suggest possible healthcare-associated pneumonia. The patient is currently on a 10-day course of Vancomycin and Cefepime, and sputum cultures should be followed up.
4. Coagulopathy: The patient has a history of DVT and is currently on Lovenox for anticoagulation. The patient's INR is elevated, and further monitoring is recommended.
5. Sacral decubitus ulcer: The patient has a stage IV sacral decubitus ulcer with a recent pseudomonal infection. The wound care recommendations should be followed, and the patient should be monitored for signs of infection.
6. Hiccups: The patient is experiencing hiccups, which may be treated with thorazine.
7. Rash: The patient has a possible drug rash, possibly related to Vancomycin.
8. Acromegaly and pituitary macroadenoma: The patient's recent labs showed normal TSH, LH, testosterone, and cortisol levels, but slightly high FSH and prolactin levels. The patient will eventually need surgical resection of the pituitary macroadenoma, but this should be deferred until the malignancy workup and treatment are complete.

The patient's current medications include:

* Metoprolol
* Enoxaparin (Lovenox)
* Vancomycin
* Cefepime
* Decadron
* Lansoprazole
* Thorazine

The patient's code status is full code, and the disposition is ICU for now. The patient's family should be involved in discussions regarding goals of care, and the patient's social worker should be contacted to facilitate this process.

 [**Last Name **] PROBLEM - ENTER DESCRIPTION IN COMMENTS
   Acute Mental Status Change, Pituitary Macroadenoma, Acromegaly
 LYMPHOMA (CANCER, MALIGNANT NEOPLASM, LYMPHOID)
   41 yo gentleman with h/o acromegaly and high grade B-cell lymphoma (s/p
   admission at [**Hospital1 1**] from [**2144-7-11**] to [**2144-11-12**]) who was transferred
   from [**Hospital6 797**] following episode of altered mental status
   that led to intubation for airway protection now s/p self extubation
   [**12-26**].
   #. Altered mental status:  Most likely due to recurrence of lymphoma in
   CNS, also some concern for infection or hemorrhage.  STAT head CT here
   (limited by motion) was able to rule out massive hemorrhage causing
   herniation, though still possibility of small hermorrhage.  Could also
   be seizure.  MRI here with ?hemorrhage versus malignancy.  In the
   setting of elevated LDH and preliminary LP results, most likely
   recurrent lymphoma.
   - Appreciate neurology consult input
   - Appreciate neurosurgery consult input
   - Appreicate BMT input
   - Appreciate neuro/onc input
   - FU final LP results and heme/path
   - Hold on further dilaudid or nortriptyline at this time, though may
   continue to give citalopram to avoid withdrawal from SSRI
   - Continue Dexamethasone 4 mg IV Q6H per Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 980**]
   - d/c Acyclovir as per neuro did not suggest it and it seems this is
   lymphoma according to LP
   - send VBG
   # Respiratory failure/Coag + Staph sputum: Sputum and consolidation on
   CXR suggest possible healthcare associated pneumonia.  Patient was
   intubated for airway protection at OSH
   - f/u sputum ctx
   - plan for 10 day course with Vancomycin/Cefepime, today is day 3 of 10
   # Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma: Patient is reportedly in remission
   after hyper-CVAD, R-[**Hospital1 **], HD methotrexate, and intrathecal
   methotrexate but LP suggests that he is having recurrence.
   - Appreciate multiple consulting services
   - FU LP results
   - [**Month (only) 11**] need full brain XRT vs methotrexate, Contact [**Name (NI) **]-Onc early Monday
   #. Rash: likely drug rash, possibly [**2-17**] Vancomycin
   #. Nausea and vomiting: Patient's original presenting complaint to [**Hospital 9798**] was nausea and vomiting. Abdominal films and upper GI
   series have yet been unrevealing.  Likely related to increased ICP
   given high opening LP pressure.
   - Treat supportively with ondansetron and dexamethasone
   - bolus 1L now then start maintenance fluids as not taking good PO
   (D51/2NS @125)
   - IV phos
   #. History of DVT in [**8-23**]: Supposed to be on Lovenox for 6 months
   after the event.
   - restarted lovenox for anticoagulation
   #. Report of abnormal EKG: Copy of EKG was not sent with patient;
   however, reportedly had diffuse ST and T changes that were attributed
   to nausea and vomiting and resulting electrolyte abnormalities. Two
   sets of cardiac enzymes were reportedly negative at [**Hospital3 1573**]. ECHO was performed and showed anteroseptal akinesis of left
   ventricle, which is new
   -EKG here unchanged from 2 prior with exception of ?U waves
   - TTE here without change from previous except dynamic LV
   # Acromegaly and Pituitary Macroadenoma: Recent labs to check HPA
   showed normal TSH, LH, testosterone, and cortisol with slightly high
   FSH (14, ULN: 12) and high prolactin at 26 (ULN: 15).
   - Will eventually need surgical resection that was to be set up on
   outpatient basis; though, appointment with neurosurgery was [**2144-12-24**]
   - Defer until malignancy workup/tx complete
   # Sacral decubitus ulcer: Reportedly a stage IV ulcer with recent
   pseudomonal infection. Appears to be without obvious infection at this
   time as drainage is serosanguinous.
   - Wound care recs applied
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: ?need for PEG
   Glycemic Control:

Summary:

The patient is a 41-year-old male with a history of acromegaly and high-grade B-cell lymphoma who was admitted to the ICU with altered mental status and respiratory failure. He was intubated for airway protection and has been receiving antibiotics and other treatments. The patient's condition has been stable, but he continues to have respiratory failure and a fever.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Recurrent Lymphoma: The patient's preliminary LP results suggest that he may have recurrent lymphoma, which could lead to further complications if not treated promptly.
2. Infection: The patient's fever and respiratory failure suggest that he may have an underlying infection, which could lead to sepsis and organ failure if not treated promptly.
3. Hemorrhage: The patient's elevated LDH and preliminary LP results suggest that he may have a small hemorrhage, which could lead to further complications if not treated promptly.
4. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure could lead to further complications if not treated promptly, such as pneumonia, acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), and respiratory failure.
5. Decubitus Ulcer: The patient's sacral decubitus ulcer could lead to further complications if not treated promptly, such as infection, sepsis, and organ failure.
6. Coagulopathy: The patient's prolonged PT and PTT suggest that he may have a coagulopathy, which could lead to further complications if not treated promptly.
7. Electrolyte Abnormalities: The patient's electrolyte abnormalities could lead to further complications if not treated promptly, such as cardiac arrhythmias, muscle weakness, and seizures.
8. Nausea and Vomiting: The patient's nausea and vomiting could lead to further complications if not treated promptly, such as dehydration, electrolyte abnormalities, and malnutrition.

Assessment and Plan:

1. Continue antibiotics and other treatments for the patient's respiratory failure and infection.
2. Monitor the patient's condition closely for signs of recurrent lymphoma, infection, hemorrhage, and respiratory failure.
3. Consider further imaging studies, such as a head CT or MRI, to evaluate the patient's condition.
4. Continue to manage the patient's electrolyte abnormalities and coagulopathy.
5. Consider further treatment options, such as surgery, radiation therapy, or chemotherapy, to manage the patient's lymphoma and other conditions.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's nutritional status and consider further nutritional support if necessary.
7. Consider further treatment options, such as anticoagulation therapy, to manage the patient's coagulopathy.
8. Continue to monitor the patient's condition closely for signs of complications and adjust treatment accordingly.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 41-year-old gentleman with a history of acromegaly and high-grade B-cell lymphoma who was admitted to the ICU due to altered mental status, respiratory failure, and sepsis.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Vital signs: Temperature 101.2°F, heart rate 96 bpm, blood pressure 145/109 mmHg, respiratory rate 24 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation 100% on nasal cannula.
* Physical examination: The patient is grunting to his eyes being opened, otherwise sleeping, and does not follow commands. He has mild dilated left pupils, reactive to light, and bilateral lower lobe subsegmental atelectasis on chest X-ray.
* Laboratory results: The patient's WBC count is 230 K/uL, Hct is 33.8%, and platelet count is 60 K/uL. His electrolyte levels are within normal limits, except for a slightly elevated potassium level. His liver function tests are mildly elevated, and his LDH is 796 IU/L.
* Imaging studies: The patient's head CT scan shows no massive hemorrhage causing herniation, but there is a possibility of small hemorrhage or seizure. His MRI is pending to rule out hemorrhage or malignancy.
* Diagnosis: The patient has diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, and his LP suggests recurrent lymphoma. He also has respiratory failure, likely due to pneumonia, and has a sacral decubitus ulcer.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Recurrent lymphoma leading to further neurological decline or sepsis
* Pneumonia progressing to respiratory failure or sepsis
* Sacral decubitus ulcer leading to infection or further tissue damage
* Electrolyte imbalances or metabolic derangements due to ongoing illness or treatment
* Cardiovascular complications due to anticoagulation therapy or underlying cardiovascular disease
* Gastrointestinal complications due to nausea, vomiting, or sepsis
* Psychiatric complications due to altered mental status or medication side effects

The patient requires close monitoring and management of his underlying conditions, as well as treatment for his current illnesses. He should be continued on vancomycin and cefepime for pneumonia, and his sacral decubitus ulcer should be managed with wound care. His electrolyte levels should be closely monitored, and his liver function tests should be repeated to ensure that they are within normal limits. His MRI should be reviewed to determine the cause of his altered mental status, and further treatment should be directed accordingly.

Summary:

The patient, a 65-year-old male, is a CNS lymphoma patient who has been admitted to the ICU for respiratory failure, acute mental status change, and altered mental status. He has been receiving treatment with radiation therapy, antibiotics, and other medications. His vital signs are stable, but he has experienced episodes of tachypnea, tachycardia, and desaturation. He has also had difficulty with NG tube placement and has been experiencing discomfort.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure is a significant concern, and he may require ongoing mechanical ventilation to support his breathing.
2. Severe sepsis: The patient's tachycardia, tachypnea, and desaturation may indicate severe sepsis, which can lead to organ dysfunction and death if not promptly treated.
3. Decubitus ulcer: The patient has a decubitus ulcer present at admission, which can lead to skin breakdown, infection, and potential sepsis.
4. Central nervous system (CNS) lymphoma progression: The patient's CNS lymphoma is a significant concern, and his altered mental status may be related to the progression of the disease.
5. Electrolyte imbalance: The patient's laboratory results show an electrolyte imbalance, which can lead to cardiac arrhythmias, muscle weakness, and other complications.
6. Infection: The patient's antibiotics and other medications may not be effective in treating his infection, which can lead to sepsis and organ dysfunction.
7. Hemodynamic instability: The patient's hemodynamic instability may be related to his sepsis, electrolyte imbalance, or other underlying conditions.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's vital signs closely and adjust his treatment plan as needed.
2. Consider the use of vasopressors to support the patient's blood pressure and perfusion.
3. Monitor the patient's respiratory status closely and consider the use of non-invasive ventilation or mechanical ventilation if necessary.
4. Continue to treat the patient's infection with antibiotics and other medications as ordered.
5. Consider the use of steroids to reduce inflammation and improve the patient's mental status.
6. Monitor the patient's electrolyte levels closely and adjust his treatment plan as needed.
7. Consider the use of anticoagulation therapy to prevent deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism.

   41 yo gentleman with h/o acromegaly and high grade B-cell lymphoma (s/p
   admission at [**Hospital1 1**] from [**2144-7-11**] to [**2144-11-12**]) who was transferred
   from [**Hospital6 797**] following episode of altered mental status
   that led to intubation for airway protection now s/p self extubation
   [**12-26**].
   #. Tachypnea and Hypoxia: Overnight has had persistent tachypnea and
   hypoxia, requiring face mask for oxygen delivery.  Possibly related to
   aspiration event overnight, but unfortunately more likely related to
   systemic lymphoma as LDH increasing.  Feel that this represents a
   significant downtown in his clinical course and XRT very unlikely to
   benefit him at this time.  Feel that he was uncomfortable overnight and
   responded to morphine.  Best course for the patient at this point is to
   become [**Month/Year (2) **] measures only.
   - Have discussed CMO with health care proxy, will be by this afternoon
   - Continue high-flow oxygen delivery in face tent form to make patient
   comfortable
   - Morphine prn for patient [**Last Name (LF) **], [**First Name3 (LF) **] need to transition to drip at
   some point today
   - Will stop antibiotics at this time, as not [**First Name3 (LF) **] measures
   - Will give 1L NS now to prevent tachycardia and perhaps help patient
   feel better on some level
 LYMPHOMA (CANCER, MALIGNANT NEOPLASM, LYMPHOID): CSF results and
   clinical picture consistent with recurrent CNS lymphoma.  Now with
   worsening altered mental status despite less sedation.
   - Scheduled for course of XRT today but given clinical deterioration,
   unlikely to benefit him and would cause more distress than benefit.
   Will stop treatments
   - Continue high-dose Decadron for palliation
   - Health care proxy updated on poor prognosis and plan
   - FU final LP results
   - Tumor lysis labs negative at this time
   #. Altered mental status:  Most likely due to recurrence of lymphoma in
   CNS, especially given LP results and increasing LDH.  Still not
   responsive except to noxious stimuli.
   - CT head yesterday not significantly changed from previous but need
   MRI to fully assess
   - FU final LP results and heme/path
   - Continue Decadron as above
   #. Increased urine output: Some concern for central diabetes insipidus
   given known increased intracranial pressure and increased urine
   output.  Now urine output has tapered off and urine appears
   concentrated based on urine lytes.
   #. Hiccups: Unclear if thorazine had benefit yesterday but can continue
   for [**First Name3 (LF) **].
   #. History of DVT in [**8-23**]: Supposed to be on Lovenox for 6 months
   after the event.
   - Will stop Lovenox given CMO status
   # Sacral decubitus ulcer: Reportedly a stage IV ulcer with recent
   pseudomonal infection. Appears to be without obvious infection at this
   time as drainage is serosanguinous.
   - Wound care recs applied for [**Date Range **]

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 41-year-old male with a history of acromegaly and high-grade B-cell lymphoma, who was admitted to the ICU with altered mental status and intubated for airway protection. He was previously treated with chemotherapy and radiation therapy.

The patient has had a significant decline in his clinical course, with persistent tachypnea and hypoxia, requiring face mask oxygen delivery. He has also had episodes of tachycardia and hiccups, and his urine output has increased, which may be related to central diabetes insipidus.

The patient's laboratory results show increasing LDH, which suggests that the lymphoma is progressing. The CT head scan shows relatively stable vasogenic edema in the temporal lobes, but there is a question of increased hypodensity in the midbrain, which may be related to ischemia.

The patient's plan of care has been changed to comfort measures only, as the clinical team feels that further treatment would not benefit him and would cause more distress. The patient is being given morphine for pain and discomfort, and his antibiotics have been stopped.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's persistent tachypnea and hypoxia may lead to respiratory failure, which could be life-threatening.
2. Sepsis: The patient's increased urine output and hiccups may be related to sepsis, which could lead to organ failure and death.
3. Central diabetes insipidus: The patient's increased urine output may be related to central diabetes insipidus, which could lead to dehydration and electrolyte imbalances.
4. Ischemia: The patient's CT head scan shows a question of increased hypodensity in the midbrain, which may be related to ischemia, which could lead to stroke or brain death.
5. Infection: The patient's sacral decubitus ulcer may become infected, which could lead to sepsis and organ failure.

The patient's code status is DNR/DNI, and his disposition is ICU for now.

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's current condition and potential medical complications as follows:

**Current Condition:**

* The patient is a 41-year-old male with a history of acromegaly and high-grade B-cell lymphoma who was admitted to the ICU due to altered mental status and intubation for airway protection.
* He has undergone self-extubation and is currently intubated due to tachypnea and hypoxia.
* The patient has a diagnosis of recurrent CNS lymphoma, with worsening altered mental status despite reduced sedation.
* He has a history of DVT, sacral decubitus ulcer, and MRSA infection.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

1. **Aspiration Pneumonia:** The patient's recent episode of tachypnea and hypoxia may be related to aspiration, which can lead to respiratory failure and potentially life-threatening complications.
2. **Central Diabetes Insipidus:** The patient's increased urine output and intracranial pressure may be indicative of central diabetes insipidus, which can lead to electrolyte imbalances and dehydration if left untreated.
3. **Thromboembolic Complications:** The patient's history of DVT and current anticoagulation with Lovenox may increase the risk of thromboembolic complications, such as pulmonary embolism or stroke.
4. **Infection:** The patient's MRSA infection and potential central nervous system (CNS) infection may lead to sepsis, meningitis, or other life-threatening complications if not promptly treated.
5. **Tumor Lysis Syndrome:** The patient's high LDH levels and potential tumor lysis may lead to electrolyte imbalances, renal failure, and cardiac arrhythmias if not managed appropriately.
6. **Seizures:** The patient's altered mental status and recent EEG pending may indicate a risk of seizures, which can be life-threatening if not managed promptly.
7. **Pulmonary Complications:** The patient's tachypnea and hypoxia may lead to respiratory failure, which can be life-threatening if not managed promptly.
8. **Gastrointestinal Complications:** The patient's history of sacral decubitus ulcer and potential gastrointestinal bleeding may lead to complications such as sepsis, perforation, or hemorrhage if not managed promptly.

In light of these potential complications, I recommend close monitoring of the patient's vital signs, respiratory status, and neurological function, as well as prompt management of any suspected infections or complications.

Summary:

The patient is a 41-year-old gentleman with a history of acromegaly and high-grade B-cell lymphoma, who was admitted to the ICU with altered mental status and intubated for airway protection. He was transferred from another hospital and has since undergone self-extubation. The patient has been diagnosed with recurrent CNS lymphoma and is currently in a comfort care only status, with all non-comfort medications stopped and no further blood draws or imaging planned. He has a history of DVT and sacral decubitus ulcer, and is currently receiving wound care and prophylaxis for DVT and stress ulcers.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Worsening Altered Mental Status: The patient's mental status has been deteriorating, and further decline could lead to increased morbidity and mortality.
2. Respiratory Complications: The patient's respiratory status is already compromised, and further deterioration could lead to respiratory failure and the need for mechanical ventilation.
3. Cardiovascular Complications: The patient's cardiovascular system is under stress due to his underlying condition, and further complications could lead to cardiac arrest or cardiac failure.
4. Infections: The patient has a history of sacral decubitus ulcer and pseudomonal infection, and there is a risk of further infection and sepsis.
5. Thrombotic Complications: The patient has a history of DVT and is currently receiving anticoagulation therapy, but further thrombotic complications could lead to pulmonary embolism or other thrombotic events.
6. Nutritional Complications: The patient is not receiving nutrition, which could lead to malnutrition and further compromise his overall health.
7. Gastrointestinal Complications: The patient has a history of stress ulcers and is receiving prophylaxis, but further complications could lead to gastrointestinal bleeding or perforation.
8. Hematological Complications: The patient has a history of lymphoma and is at risk for further hematological complications, such as bleeding or anemia.
9. Neurological Complications: The patient has a history of CNS lymphoma and is at risk for further neurological complications, such as seizures or increased intracranial pressure.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 41-year-old gentleman with a history of acromegaly and high-grade B-cell lymphoma who was admitted to the hospital after an episode of altered mental status that led to intubation for airway protection. He was transferred to the ICU from another hospital and has since undergone self-extubation.

The patient is currently experiencing tachypnea and hypoxia, which is likely related to systemic lymphoma and not aspiration. His condition has significantly deteriorated, and XRT is unlikely to benefit him at this time. The patient has been made "comfort measures only" and is receiving high-flow oxygen delivery in a face tent form, morphine drip for comfort, and PRN fluid boluses to help manage his tachycardia.

The patient's altered mental status is likely due to the recurrence of lymphoma in the CNS, given the LP results and increasing LDH. His urine output is increased, which may be related to central diabetes insipidus given the known increased intracranial pressure.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's tachypnea and hypoxia may worsen, leading to respiratory failure.
2. Cardiovascular instability: The patient's tachycardia and increased urine output may indicate cardiovascular instability, which could lead to cardiac arrhythmias or cardiac failure.
3. Neurological deterioration: The patient's altered mental status and increasing LDH may indicate further neurological deterioration, which could lead to loss of consciousness or even death.
4. Infection: The patient has a sacral decubitus ulcer with recent pseudomonal infection, which may become infected again, leading to sepsis or septic shock.
5. Metabolic disturbances: The patient's increased urine output and potential central diabetes insipidus may lead to electrolyte imbalances, such as hypokalemia or hypomagnesemia.
6. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's increased urine output may lead to dehydration, electrolyte imbalances, and gastrointestinal complications such as nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea.
7. Hematological complications: The patient's high-grade B-cell lymphoma may lead to hematological complications such as bleeding or thrombocytopenia.
8. Renal failure: The patient's increased urine output may indicate renal failure, which could lead to acute kidney injury or chronic kidney disease.

Based on the patient's condition and potential complications, it is essential to closely monitor his vital signs, laboratory results, and medical status to adjust his care accordingly and provide optimal comfort and support.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 41-year-old male with a history of acromegaly and high-grade B-cell lymphoma who was admitted to the ICU due to altered mental status, which led to intubation for airway protection. He was previously treated with radiation therapy (XRT) but has now developed metastatic disease to the brain.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Vital signs: Tachypnea, hypoxia, tachycardia, and hypertension
* Respiratory support: Face mask with high-flow oxygen delivery
* Neurological status: Altered mental status, not responsive to verbal or tactile stimuli
* Cardiovascular status: Sinus tachycardia, normal blood pressure
* Hemodynamic monitoring: Normal central venous pressure, normal pulmonary artery pressure
* Fluid balance: Negative fluid balance due to excessive urine output
* Laboratory results:
	+ Complete Blood Count (CBC): WBC 6.7, Hct 33.2, Plt 189
	+ Blood chemistry: Sodium 136 mg/dL, Potassium 4.2 mg/dL, Creatinine 0.4 mg/dL, Uric acid 3.9 mg/dL
	+ Lactic acid: 2.3 mmol/L
	+ Liver function tests: ALT 8 IU/L, AST 27 IU/L, Alk Phos 73 IU/L, T Bili 0.3 mg/dL
	+ Kidney function tests: BUN 14 mg/dL, Creatinine 0.4 mg/dL
* Imaging studies: None new

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's tachypnea and hypoxia may worsen, leading to respiratory failure.
2. Sepsis: The patient's increasing LDH and WBC count may indicate an underlying infection, which can lead to sepsis.
3. Central diabetes insipidus: The patient's increased urine output and decreased serum sodium may indicate central diabetes insipidus.
4. Neurological deterioration: The patient's altered mental status may worsen, leading to neurological deterioration.
5. Cardiovascular instability: The patient's tachycardia and hypertension may worsen, leading to cardiovascular instability.
6. Infection: The patient's sacral decubitus ulcer may become infected, leading to sepsis.
7. Tumor lysis syndrome: The patient's high LDH and WBC count may indicate tumor lysis syndrome, which can lead to electrolyte imbalances and renal failure.

The patient's treatment plan includes:

1. Continue high-flow oxygen delivery in face tent form to make the patient comfortable.
2. Morphine drip for patient comfort.
3. PRN fluid boluses to help treat tachycardia and perhaps help the patient feel better on some level.
4. Stop Lovenox due to the patient's status.
5. Wound care recommendations for comfort.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's neurological status and adjust treatment accordingly.
7. Consider further imaging studies to evaluate the patient's central nervous system and assess for any new lesions.

Overall, the patient's condition is critical, and close monitoring and management are necessary to prevent complications and improve his outcomes.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 41-year-old gentleman with a history of acromegaly and high-grade B-cell lymphoma, who was admitted to the ICU with altered mental status and intubated for airway protection. The patient has been diagnosed with recurrent CNS lymphoma and is currently in a comfort care only status.

The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 36.4°C (97.6°F) and 35.6°C (96°F) over the past 24 hours
* Heart rate: 125 beats per minute (bpm) with a normal sinus rhythm
* Blood pressure: 123/60 mmHg and 104/48 mmHg over the past 24 hours
* Respiratory rate: 12 breaths per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 88%

The patient's physical examination is notable for:

* Obtunded mental status, not responsive to verbal or tactile stimuli
* Rhonchi bilaterally on anterior exam, increased from yesterday
* 2+ bilateral lower extremity pitting edema
* Soft and non-tender abdomen

Laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 6.7-9.3 x 10^9/L
* Hemoglobin: 12.9-14 g/dL
* Platelet count: 189-8.3 x 10^9/L
* Blood urea nitrogen: 136-139 mg/dL
* Creatinine: 0.4-0.5 mg/dL
* Glucose: 90-136 mg/dL
* Lactic acid: 2.3 mmol/L
* Albumin: 3.6 g/dL
* LDH: 1081 IU/L
* Calcium: 8.4 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 2.0 mg/dL
* Phosphorus: 2.6 mg/dL

The patient has a history of DVT and is currently on Lovenox, but will stop due to his CMO status. He also has a sacral decubitus ulcer with recent pseudomonal infection, which is currently without obvious infection.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Further deterioration of the patient's mental status and respiratory function
* Development of sepsis or septic shock due to the patient's immunocompromised state and presence of a sacral decubitus ulcer
* Increased risk of bleeding due to the patient's thrombocytopenia and platelet dysfunction
* Potential for further metastatic disease to other parts of the body, including the brain, spinal cord, and bone marrow
* Development of respiratory failure or acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) due to the patient's underlying lung disease and respiratory muscle weakness
* Increased risk of infection due to the patient's immunocompromised state and presence of central lines and catheters.

Based on the patient's condition and the comfort care only status, the focus should be on providing palliative care to manage the patient's symptoms and improve his quality of life. This may include adjusting his medication regimen, providing wound care for the sacral decubitus ulcer, and addressing any other medical issues that may arise.

The patient, a 41-year-old gentleman with a history of acromegaly and high-grade B-cell lymphoma, is currently in the ICU with worsening altered mental status despite reduced sedation. He has a diagnosis of recurrent CNS lymphoma with metastases to the brain. The patient's condition is critical, and he is now receiving comfort measures only.

The patient's vital signs are as follows:

* Temperature: 36.4°C (97.6°F) to 35.6°C (96°F)
* Heart rate: 125 bpm (116-125 bpm)

* Respiratory rate: 12 breaths per minute (5-16 breaths per minute)
* Oxygen saturation: 88%

The patient has a diagnosis of sepsis, as evidenced by the presence of a moderate growth of Staphylococcus aureus on a sputum culture. He also has a sacral decubitus ulcer, which is reportedly a stage IV ulcer with a recent pseudomonal infection.

The patient's laboratory results are as follows:

* White blood cell count: 6.7-9.3 x 10^9/L
* Hemoglobin: 12.9-14.0 g/dL
* Platelet count: 189-221 x 10^9/L
* Creatinine: 0.3-0.5 mg/dL
* Blood urea nitrogen: 14-20 mg/dL
* Electrolyte levels: normal
* Albumin: 3.6 g/dL
* Lactic acid: 2.3 mmol/L
* LDH: 1081 IU/L
* Ca++: 8.4 mg/dL
* Mg++: 2.0 mg/dL
* PO4: 2.6 mg/dL

The patient's imaging studies are as follows:

* No new imaging studies were performed.

The patient's treatment plan is as follows:

* Comfort measures only
* All non-comfort medications stopped
* No blood draws or imaging studies
* Health care proxy being updated regularly
* Waist measurement to be taken today per the patient's request
* Final LP results to be obtained
* Hiccups: Unclear if thorazine is having benefit, but can continue for comfort
* Wound care recommendations applied for comfort
* ICU care, including nutrition, glycemic control, and prophylaxis for DVT, stress ulcer, and VAP.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's condition include:

* Sepsis and septic shock due to the presence of a moderate growth of Staphylococcus aureus on a sputum culture
* Worsening of the patient's altered mental status and potential for increased intracranial pressure
* Development of further metastases to the brain or other organs
* Complications related to the patient's sacral decubitus ulcer, such as infection or bleeding
* Development of respiratory failure or cardiac arrest due to the patient's underlying condition.

It is essential to closely monitor the patient's condition and adjust his treatment plan accordingly to prevent or manage these potential complications.
